subject: Keyboard remapping
msgSnippet: To everyone: I have essentially completed setting up a new keyboard scheme for typing Quikscript building on the ideas that Jon Zuck proposed recently along
messageBody:
To everyone:

I have essentially completed setting up a new keyboard scheme for typing
Quikscript building on the ideas that Jon Zuck proposed recently along
with some additions of my own. The Keyman program allows me to type in
a scheme that is easy to remember due to its relationship to Roman, and
Keyman functions as an interface altering the actual input so that the
appropriate QS letters appear on the screen in the Jerome font. Now
that I understand it somewhat, I realize why Keyman allows a file or
post typed in this new scheme to be read by someone using the standard
Shavian mapping in a Shavian font: Keyman functions like an overlay of
the existing Jerome mapping, which is the standard Shavian mapping plus
the extensions added to take advantage of the QS half-letters and
ligatures.

After using Keyman and this new typing scheme, I can assure you it will
be much easier to master than what we have been struggling with. To
take advantage of this, you will have to download Keyman 3.1 from the
website tavultesoft.com. It is free. Then download the following files
from Read_Alphabet: ezqs.kmn, ezqson.bmp, ezqs.off.bmp and ezqs.notes
The first file contains the program that insructs Keyman how to alter
your input on the keyboard to the appropriate Jerome output. The second
and third file are bitmaps used as buttons on the screen to turn Keyman
on and off. The last file explains the keystrokes used and
corresponding Jerome output. The notes file is not completed yet, but
you can still download the others. I upload the notes file as soon as I
can.

The basic idea is that almost all the consonants are typed as one would
expect. The digraphs (sh, ch, th, zh,) as typed as they would be in
Roman and the appropriate QS character is output. The ligature letters
(involving a vowel + 'r') are mapped to the numbers 4, 5, 6, 7, 8.
After typing the number, you type 'j', which acts as a 'flag.' Since
'j' is struck with a strong finger and can only be used after certain
consonants, it is used as a 'flag' key for other combinations as well.
The half-letters are produced by typing the appropriate letter
immediately followed by 'j.' This also produces the alternate 'n'
character and the alternate schwa. Respectively, 'nj' and 'aj.' Since
'nj' is a letter combination that can occur, when that is what one
needs, but the alternate 'n' has been output to the screen, simply hit
the 'j' a second time, and the output shifts to 'nj' as needed.

The vowels are triggered by typing combinations that are used in Roman.
Using the names in the QS manual, the following combinations give the
related output.
ee, ea, ey = EAt;
ay, ai = EIGHt
aa = At
ie, yy = I
oh = OWE
oo = fOOt
aw = AWE
ah = Ah
ou, ow = OUt
oi, oy = OY

Since the letter sequence 'a+w' and 'a+h' can occur in English words,
when the program gives you an 'Ah' or 'AWE' that you don't want, simply
hit the 'h' or 'w' a second time, and the output will shift back to the
separate letters.

The only problem still remaining at this time that I am aware of is that
the two "x" forms were mapped by Jon to require the use of the 'alt'
key, and I have not been able to map that to the 'x' key as I had
hoped. It still works with Keyman, but you have to type 'alt' 0232 or
'alt' 0233 to get the 'x' forms.

I would like to see some posts back and forth using this new setup so we
can see how well it works and whether there are any bugs that need to be
fixed.

One of the fortuitous things about this scheme is that it works equally
well for junior and senior QS. A person just learning the alphabet can
ignore the parts intended for senior QS with no problem, but they are
there when the person is ready to move on the advanced form.

Let me know what you think.

Thanks.

Paige Gabhart
